Principal ASIC Design Engineer LSI Corporation April 2007  –  November 2014  (7 years 8 months) Team leadership, architecture, design, synthesis, testability, and static timing of a high-speed deep sub-micron SOC devices for the telecommunications and networking industry. Distinguished Member of Technical Staff Agere Systems, Inc. March 2002  –  April 2007  (5 years 2 months) Team leadership, architecture, design, synthesis and testability of a high-speed deep sub-micron SOC devices for the telecommunications industry. Senior Digital Design Engineer Improv Systems, Inc March 2000  –  March 2002  (2 years 1 month) Author of US Patent Application 20010025363, Designer Configurable Multi- 
Processor System, Serial Number 09/757,373 filed with the U.S. Patent Office on; Co-author of two additional internal applications for patent, 
dealing with the Jazz processor instruction compression scheme, and the ability to 
auto-generate processors which use designer defined computational units as RTL 
based hard code blocks. 
 
· Acted as technical support to many of the designers for various architectural and 
tool related issues. 
· Evolution of environment and system to automatically generate RTL, synthesize, and 
simulate a user defined representation of the Improv Systems Inc. Jazz 2.1 
Processor Architecture. This work included the insertion of debug circuitry into 
the Jazz 2.1 Processor Architecture. Required creation of automated scripts to 
generate and insert scan chains into the specified processor so that these scan 
chains could be used by the debug circuitry to read current state of the processor. Senior ASIC Design Engineer Intrinsix Corp February 1999  –  March 2000  (1 year 2 months) Design-Compiler based automatic synthesis methodology for 
the Digital Signal Processor division of Texas Instruments. This consisted of sets 
of scripts (DC-shell and C-shell) which can be used by a designer to compile a 
hierarchical design and achieve quick turn around of design modifications. This 
script gives the designer flexibility to modify constraints for any sub-block of 
the design as he sees fit in a simple and uniform manner. This synthesis suite was 
used to synthesize the Multi-Channel Buffered Serial Port (MCBSP) Texas Instruments 
GS30ka 0.15 micron technology running at 100MHz. 
· Developed Synopsys, Inc. Design-Compiler based synthesis methodology for a wireless 
communications division of Nortel Networks. The flow had to handle both manually 
generated RTL code which follows a set of design guidelines and also code which was 
automatically generated via Cadence Design Systems, Inc. Signal Processing 
Workbench (SPW) toolset. This consisted of sets of scripts (DC-shell and C-shell) 
which can be used by a designer to compile a hierarchical design using the standard 
two-pass, compile-characterize-writescript-recompile methodology for greatest 
flexibility in quick turn around of design modifications. This synthesis suite was 
used to synthesize a set of three (3) ASICs, the largest of which was an ~1.1 
million gate design using Texas Instruments GS30 0.15 micron technology running at 
100MHz. 
· Responsible for integration and debug of Intrinsix uplatform® transactor based 
design environment with Cadence Design Systems, Inc. Affirma NC (Native Compiled) 
mixed-mode Verilog and VHDL simulator. 
· Performed evaluation of synthesis techniques used by customer for an ~4M gate 
graphics chip. This analysis consisted of testing their environment, code 
evaluation, and re-architecting of block designs. Principal ASIC Design Engineer Cadence Design Systems, Inc January 1997  –  February 1999  (2 years 2 months) · Developed address table memory interleaved memory access controller block for an 
ATM chipset to meet customer specifications. Multiple interleaved state machines 
allow for normal memory accesses for passing and possible modification of ATM data 
cells as well as interleaving system memory access requests with the data stream. 
Designed to trigger multiple fault detects based upon invalid parity or invalid 
data reads from non-filled address locations. Designed using behavioral VHDL code 
as customer input to flow. Responsibilities included micro-architectural 
specifications, RTL design, synthesis, simulation and static timing analysis. 
Design used full scan test methodology (Approx. 200k gates). 
· Developed synthesis scripts for automated synthesis of VHDL or Verilog RTL design 
into gates which was used by entire department. Script uses Synopsys, Inc. Design 
Compiler scripts, UNIX shell scripts as well as a TK toolkit front end. This script 
was used as the basis for the development of a synthesis suite which was 
distributed company wide for use by the entire Front End ASIC Design community. 
· Performed setup for and running of static timing analysis for ~800K gate ATM chip, 
with I/O speeds approaching 200MHz and an average operating frequency of 67MHz. 
This analysis was performed using Cadence Design Systems, Inc. Pearl Static Timing 
Analysis Tool. 
· Acted as design support for various other members of our design team. During my 
role as synthesis lead, I worked with the other designers to help modify their code 
in order to allow for better synthesis with respect to design speed and area 
constraints. This required a knowledge not only of the synthesis tools but also an 
ability to quickly see what the original designers intentions were and be able to 
parse out a better version of code for the synthesis tool to work with. Senior ASIC Design Engineer Eastman Kodak Company June 1988  –  January 1997  (8 years 8 months) · Developed department design flow for use with the Motorola design library suite. 
This design flow included the generation of a set of UNIX and Synopsys scripts 
which can be used to reinsert hierarchy back into the design after Motorola returns 
a flat Verilog netlist of the design, post-layout. 
· Developed department design flow for design verification using the LSI libraries 
and VHDL VITAL simulations with complete SDF back-annotation capability. 
· Two patents granted for CD WORM drive wobble data read circuitry. Patent numbers 
5,506,824 (Frequency modulation to biphase data conversion for writeable CD ATIP
